item.title: Natalie add a quote by William Makepeace Thackeray
item.description: "All is vanity, nothing is fair." -- William Makepeace Thackeray

item.title: Natalie add a quote by John Stuart Mill
item.description: "I have learned to seek my happiness by limiting my desires, rather than in attempting to satisfy them." -- John Stuart Mill

item.title: Natalie add a quote by Harold Bloom
item.description: "We read frequently if unknowingly, in quest of a mind more original than our own." -- Harold Bloom

item.title: Natalie add a quote by Charlotte Brontë
item.description: "I am no bird; and no net ensnares me: I am a free human being with an independent will." -- Charlotte Brontë

item.title: Natalie add a quote by Paul Farmer
item.description: "It is very expensive to give bad medical care to poor people in a rich country." -- Paul Farmer

item.title: Natalie add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Full fathom five thy father lies; Of his bones are coral made; Those are pearls that were his eyes: Nothing of him that doth fade, But doth suffer a sea-change Into something rich and strange. Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell: Ding-dong Hark! now I hear them,—Ding-dong, bell." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Natalie add a quote by Emma Thompson
item.description: "Piracy is our only option." -- Emma Thompson

item.title: Natalie add a quote by John Stewart Mill
item.description:
"I did not mean that Conservatives are generally stupid; I meant, that stupid persons are generally Conservative. I believe that to be so obvious and undeniable a fact that I hardly think any hon. Gentleman will question it.
[<i>John Stuart Mill, in a Parliamentary debate with the Conservative MP, John Pakington, May 31, 1866</i>.]" -- John Stewart Mill

item.title: Natalie add a quote by Emily Dickinson
item.description: "There is no frigate like a book To take us lands away, Nor any coursers like a page Of prancing poetry. This traverse may the poorest take Without oppress of toll; How frugal is the chariot That bears a human soul!" -- Emily Dickinson

item.title: Natalie add a quote by John Donne
item.description:
"As virtuous men pass mildly away, And whisper to their souls to go, Whilst some of their sad friends do say, "The breath goes now," and some say, "No,"
So let us melt, and make no noise, No tear-floods, nor sigh-tempests move; 'Twere profanation of our joys To tell the laity our love.
Moving of the earth brings harms and fears, Men reckon what it did and meant; But trepidation of the spheres, Though greater far, is innocent.
Dull sublunary lovers' love (Whose soul is sense) cannot admit Absence, because it doth remove Those things which elemented it.
But we, by a love so much refined That our selves know not what it is, Inter-assured of the mind, Care less, eyes, lips, and hands to miss.
Our two souls therefore, which are one, Though I must go, endure not yet A breach, but an expansion. Like gold to airy thinness beat.
If they be two, they are two so As stiff twin compasses are two: Thy soul, the fixed foot, makes no show To move, but doth, if the other do;
And though it in the center sit, Yet when the other far doth roam, It leans, and hearkens after it, And grows erect, as that comes home.
Such wilt thou be to me, who must, Like the other foot, obliquely run; Thy firmness makes my circle just, And makes me end where I begun." -- John Donne

item.title: Natalie add a quote by John Muir
item.description: "One touch of nature makes the whole world kin." -- John Muir

item.title: Natalie add a quote by Dr. Seuss
item.description: "Don't cry because it's over, smile because it happened." -- Dr. Seuss

item.title: Natalie add a quote by Eleanor Roosevelt
item.description: "No one can make you feel inferior without your consent." -- Eleanor Roosevelt

item.title: Natalie add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "The fool doth think he is wise, but the wise man knows himself to be a fool." -- William Shakespeare
